facts.text: Appeal from the Judgment and Decree dated 19th June, 1950, of the High Court of Judicature at Calcutta Das and Guha JJ.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the Judgment and Decree dated 19th June, 1950, of the High Court of Judicature at Calcutta  Das and Guha JJ.  in Appeal from Original Decree No. 48 of 1949.arising out of Judgment and Decree dated the 22nd December, 1948, of the Court of the Subordinate Judge, 3rd Court,24-Parganas, in Title Suit No. 53 of 1944.

facts.text: Judgment and Decree dated the 22nd December, 1948, of the Court of the Subordinate Judge, 3rd Court,24-Parganas, in Title Suit No. 53 of 1944.

anchor.surface_text: in Appeal from Original Decree No. 48 of 1949.arising out of Judgment and Decree dated the 22nd December, 1948, of the Court of the Subordinate Judge, 3rd Court,24-Parganas, in Title Suit No. 53 of 1944. C. Chatterjee  A. K. Dutt, with him  for the appellants. Panchanan Ghose  Radha Kanta Bhattacharya, with him  for the respondent. 1953. January 16.

facts.text: The facts material for our present purpose are number in dispute.

anchor.surface_text: those of the Subordinate Judge, Third Court, 24-Parganas, passed in Title Suit No. 53 of 1944. The facts material for our present purpose are number in dispute and the companytroversy between the parties practically centres round one short point, namely, whether or number the plaintiffs suit is barred by limitation.

facts.text: Subject-matter of dispute is one-third share of shebaiti right in respect of a private debutter dedicated to an idol known by the name of Dakshineshwar Jew situated at village Dhop Dhopi in 24-Parganas, West Bengal.

anchor.surface_text: The trial companyrt decided this point in favour of the plaintiffs, while the High Court has taken a companytrary view in appeal. The subject-matter of dispute is one-third share of shebaiti right in respect of a private debutter dedicated to an idol known by the name of Dakshineshwar Jew and situated at a village called Dhop Dhopi within the district of 24-Parganas in West Bengal.

facts.text: Deity is ancient, reputed founder and first shebait was Udhab Chandra Pandit.

anchor.surface_text: The deity is an ancient one and its reputed founder and first shebait was one Udhab Chandra Pandit. It is number disputed that by successive devolutions the rights of the shebait came to vest in one Iswar Chandra Chakroborti, who was the companymon ancestor of the parties to this suit.

facts.text: Rights of shebait vested in Iswar Chandra Chakroborti, common ancestor of parties.

anchor.surface_text: It is number disputed that by successive devolutions the rights of the shebait came to vest in one Iswar Chandra Chakroborti, who was the companymon ancestor of the parties to this suit. The following genealogical table will make clear the relationship of the several persons who figure as parties.

facts.text: Iswar died leaving six sons: Ashutosh, Govinda, Gopal, Sadananda, Trailokhya and Haran.

anchor.surface_text: Iswar died leaving six sons as his heirs and they were Ashutosh, Govinda, Gopal, Sadananda, Trailokhya and Haran. These six sons when they divided the properties of their father, divided the shebaiti right also which devolved upon them in six equal shares,

facts.text: Six sons divided shebaiti right into six equal shares by palas or turns of worship, 5 days every month each.

anchor.surface_text: These six sons when they divided the properties of their father, divided the shebaiti right also which devolved upon them in six equal shares, and this division was by the method known as palas or turns of worship, which means that to each one of the sons was allotted the right of worshipping the deity for 5 days every month and during these days he alone was to discharge the functions of the shebait and receive the emoluments attached to the office.

facts.text: Custom grew up in family to buy and sell palas amongst members.

anchor.surface_text: Gradually, a custom grew up in the family according to which these palas companyld be bought and sold or otherwise alienated amongst the members of the shebaits family.

facts.text: Govinda, father of plaintiffs, sold his 5 days pala to Haran, so Haran acquired 10 days pala or one-third share.

anchor.surface_text: Govinda, who was the father of the plaintiffs and who got 5, days pala every month in his share, sold his interest in the shebaiti to Haran, a brother of his, and the result was that Haran acquired 10 days pala every mouth or one-third share in the entire shebaiti right.

facts.text: Haran died without issue, leaving widow Rajlakshmi as sole heir.

anchor.surface_text: Haran died without any issue leaving him surviving, his widow Rajlakshmi as his sole heir under the Hindu law and Rajlakshmi companytinued to hold this one- third share of shebaiti right along with other properties of the deceased.

facts.text: On 17th June, 1920, Rajlakshmi granted ijara lease of her shebaiti right for two years to Satish Chandra Dey.

anchor.surface_text: On 17th June, 1920, Rajlakshmi granted an ijara lease of her shebaiti right for a term of two years to one Satish Chandra Dey. On 1st of April, 1921, Satish sold this leasehold interest in respect to the palas to one Ram Rakhal Ghose.

facts.text: On 1st April, 1921, Satish sold leasehold interest to Ram Rakhal Ghose.

anchor.surface_text: On 1st of April, 1921, Satish sold this leasehold interest in respect to the palas to one Ram Rakhal Ghose. Previous to that, on 6th of August, 1920, Ram Rakhal had himself taken a lease from Rajlakshmi of her shebaiti right for a period of 5 years,

facts.text: On 6th August, 1920, Ram Rakhal took lease from Rajlakshmi for 5 years commencing after Satish's lease.

anchor.surface_text: Previous to that, on 6th of August, 1920, Ram Rakhal had himself taken a lease from Rajlakshmi of her shebaiti right for a period of 5 years, this lease to companymence at the close of the previous lease in favour of Satish.

facts.text: Ram Rakhal got possession of shebait office from 1st April, 1921.

anchor.surface_text: Ram Rakhal admittedly got possession of the office of shebait and began to exercise his rights as such on and from the 1st of April, 1921. By a deed of companyveyance dated the 7th of November, 1921, Rajlakshmi made an out and out sale of her shebaiti right in favour of Ram Rakhal

facts.text: By deed dated 7th November, 1921, Rajlakshmi sold shebaiti right to Ram Rakhal.

anchor.surface_text: By a deed of companyveyance dated the 7th of November, 1921, Rajlakshmi made an out and out sale of her shebaiti right in favour of Ram Rakhal and twenty days after this purchase, that is to say, on 27th November, 1921, Ram Rakhal in his turn sold this interest to Nagendra and Surendra,

facts.text: On 27th November, 1921, Ram Rakhal sold interest to Nagendra and Surendra, sons of Trailokhya.

anchor.surface_text: and twenty days after this purchase, that is to say, on 27th November, 1921, Ram Rakhal in his turn sold this interest to Nagendra and Surendra, two of the sons of Trailokhya. Surendra died some time afterwards and on 20th of June, 1925, his widow Tarakali sold her husbands share

facts.text: Surendra died, on 20th June 1925 Tarakali sold his share to Nagendra.

anchor.surface_text: Surendra died some time afterwards and on 20th of June, 1925, his widow Tarakali sold her husbands share in the shebaiti right to Nagendra, her husbands brother. Thus Nagendra in addition to what he had inherited from his own father came to hold the entirety of a third share

facts.text: Nagendra held entirety of one-third shebaiti right (10 days pala).

anchor.surface_text: Thus Nagendra in addition to what he had inherited from his own father came to hold the entirety of a third share in the shebaiti right, represented by 10 days pala every mouth, which was previously hold by Haran. Rajlakshmi died on 22nd December, 1943,

facts.text: Rajlakshmi died on 22nd December, 1943.

anchor.surface_text: which was previously hold by Haran. Rajlakshmi died on 22nd December, 1943, and the two plaintiffs, who are the two surviving sons of Govinda, filed the suit out of which this appeal arises for recovery of possession of this one-third shebaiti right of Haran

facts.text: Plaintiffs are two surviving sons of Govinda, filed suit for recovery of possession as next heirs of Haran.

anchor.surface_text: Rajlakshmi died on 22nd December, 1943, and the two plaintiffs, who are the two surviving sons of Govinda, filed the suit out of which this appeal arises for recovery of possession of this one-third shebaiti right of Haran on the allegation that they were the next heirs of Haran at the time of Rajlakshmis death.

facts.text: Nagendra died before suit, defendant 1 Palani Bala minor daughter represented by husband, deft 2 receiver.

anchor.surface_text: Nagendra had died in the meantime and the first and the principal defendant in the suit is his daughter Palani Bala, who is a minor and is represented by her husband as guardian. The second defendant is the receiver, who has been placed in charge of the properties of Palani Bala in a guardianship proceeding pending before the District Judge of 24Parganas.

facts.text: Trial Judge decreed for plaintiffs on 22nd December 1948.

anchor.surface_text: The trial Judge by his judgment dated the 22nd December 1948, overruled the pleas taken by the defendant and gave the plaintiffs a decree.

facts.text: High Court reversed trial court, dismissed suit.

anchor.surface_text: In this view, the judgment of the trial companyrt was reversed and the plaintiffs suit dismissed.

facts.text: Plaintiffs claim reversioners after Rajlakshmi, entitled to possession.

anchor.surface_text: The case of the plaintiffs, in substance, is that the one- third share of the shebaiti right, which was held by Haran during his lifetime, devolved upon his widow Rajlakshmi who had only the restricted rights of a Hindu widow in respect to the same. On the death of the widow, the interest vested in the plaintiffs.

issues.text: whether or not the plaintiffs suit is barred by limitation

anchor.surface_text: namely, whether or number the plaintiffs suit is barred by limitation. The trial companyrt decided this point in favour of the plaintiffs, while the High Court has taken a companytrary view in appeal. The subject-matter of dispute is one-third share of shebaiti right in respect of a private debutter dedicated to an idol known by the name of Dakshineshwar Jew and situated at a village called Dhop Dhopi within the district of 24-Parganas in West Bengal.

issues.text: whether on the facts of the present case the plaintiffs suit is governed by article 124 or article 141 of the Limitation Act

anchor.surface_text: The first is, whether on the facts of the present case the plaintiffs suit is governed by article 124 or article 141 of the Limitation Act ? If article 141 is the appropriate article, it is number disputed that the plaintiffs suit is well within time but if -article 124 is applicable, the other point that would require consideration is, when did the defendant or her predecessors take possession of the hereditary office of shebait adversely to the plaintiffs ?

issues.text: when did the defendant or her predecessors take possession of the hereditary office of shebait adversely to the plaintiffs ? Was their possession adverse from the very date of the transfer by Rajlakshmi or did it become so only at her death ?

anchor.surface_text: the other point that would require consideration is, when did the defendant or her predecessors take possession of the hereditary office of shebait adversely to the plaintiffs ? Was their possession adverse from the very date of the transfer by Rajlakshmi or did it become so only at her death ? The proposition is well established that the alienation of the shebaiti right by a shebait in favour of a stranger is absolutely void in Hindu law and cannot be validated even on the footing of a custom.

issues.text: whether the present suit is governed by article 124 or article 141 of the Limitation Act

anchor.surface_text: Coming now to the specific points raised in the case, the first thing that requires consideration is, whether the present suit is governed by article 124 or article 141 of the Limitation Act ? The learned Judges of the High Court have held and quite properly that the benefit of article 141 could be claimed only if there was a qualified estate in the female heir after whose death the plaintiff was entitled to the property as the heir of the last male holder.

arguments.claim: Plaintiffs suit is barred by limitation because sale by Rajlakshmi was void, making possession of Ram Rakhal and vendees adverse against all shebaits, acquiring indefeasible title by adverse possession

anchor.surface_text: The suit was resisted on behalf of defendant No. 1 and the main contention raised was that as the sale of her shebaiti right by Rajlakshmi, the widow of Haran, was a void transaction which did number create any right in the transferee, the possession of Ram Rakhal and after him his vendees, who were the predecessors of defendant No. 1 , was adverse against all the shebaits, and the defendant No. 1 consequently acquired an -indefeasible title to this third share in the shebaiti right by adverse possession and the plaintiffs suit was barred by limitation.

arguments.claim: Article 141 not attracted but suit not barred: Nagendra purchased only life interest of Rajlakshmi, recognizing reversioners; no adverse possession as co-shebaits without ouster

anchor.surface_text: On the question of limitation, the Subordinate Judge held that although article 141 of the Indian Limitation Act was number attracted to this cage, yet the plaintiffs suit was number barred by limitation. Two reasons have been assigned for this view. It has been said in the first place that Nagendra purported to purchase only the life interest of Rajlakshmi consequently his position as purchaser was in recognition of the interest of the reversionary heirs of Haran.

anchor.surface_text: It was held by the High Court that the proper article to apply in this case was article 124 of the Limitation Act, and as the defendant No. 1 and her predecessors had been in possession of the hereditary office of the shebait adversely to the plaintiff for more than 12 years prior to the institution of the suit, the plaintiffs claim was barred by limitation.

anchor.surface_text: It may be mentioned at the outset that in the old Limitation Act  Act XXIV of 1859  there was numberspecific provision relating to suits by reversioners... adverse possession which bars her bars the heir after her...

arguments.claim: 1871 Act Art 142 (now 141) deliberately changed law to fresh start from female's death for reversioners

anchor.surface_text: In 1871 a new Limitation Act was passed which repealed the earlier Act of 1859. Article 142 of this Act  which corresponds to article 141 of the present Act  expressly prescribed a period of limitation of 12 years for a suit by a Hindu entitled to possession of immovable property on the death of a Hindu female heir...

arguments.claim: Suit governed by Art 124 not 141: shebaiti right is hereditary office, not immovable property

anchor.surface_text: Coming now to the specific points raised in the case, the first thing that requires consideration is, whether the present suit is governed by article 124 or article 141 of the Limitation Act ? ... it is quite settled that a shebaiti right is a hereditary office and as such companyes within the express language of article 124 of the Limitation Act.

arguments.claim: Under Art 124 + s2(8), adverse possession must be to plaintiff or person through whom derives right to sue; starts at widow's death

anchor.surface_text: Article 124 relates to a suit for possession of a hereditary office... Reading article 124 of the Limitation Act along with section 2  8 , the conclusion is irresistible that to defeat the title of the plaintiff under article 124 it is necessary to establish that the defendant had taken possession of the office adversely to the plaintiff or somebody from or through whom the plaintiff derives his title...

arguments.claim: Female shebait holds widow's limited estate in shebaiti right

anchor.surface_text: a shebaitship, as is number well settled, combines in it both the elements of office and property. As the shebaiti interest is heritable and follows the line of inheritance from the founder obviously when the heir is a female, she must be deemed to have, what is known, as widows estate in the shebaiti interest.

holdings.text: The alienation of the shebaiti right by a shebait in favour of a stranger is absolutely void in Hindu law and cannot be validated even on the footing of a custom. The alienee of the right is, therefore, a trespasser and his possession as against the transferor is adverse from the very beginning.

anchor.surface_text: The proposition is well established that the alienation of the shebaiti right by a shebait in favour of a stranger is absolutely void in Hindu law and cannot be validated even on the footing of a custom. The alienee of the right is, therefore, a trespasser

holdings.reasoning_summary: Well-established proposition of Hindu law applied to facts; alienee trespasser from start against transferor.

holdings.text: Adverse possession against a Hindu widow does not bar the reversioners as they do not derive title through her; cause of action accrues on her death, principle recognized since 1871 and applies generally beyond Art 141.

anchor.surface_text: the law can now be taken to be perfectly well settled that except where a decree has been obtained fairly and properly and without fraud and collusion against the Hindu female heir in respect to a property held by her as a limited owner, the cause of action for a suit

holdings.reasoning_summary: Historical evolution from 1859 Act, deliberate legislative change in 1871 Art 142/141, affirmed by Privy Council precedents like Ranchordas v Parvati; reversioners' spes successionis not through widow.

holdings.text: A shebaitship combines both elements of office and property; heritable following inheritance; female heir holds it as widow's limited estate.

anchor.surface_text: Whatever might be said about the office of a trustee, which carries no beneficial interest with it, a shebaitship, as is not well settled, combines in it both the elements of office and property. As the shebaiti interest is heritable and follows the line of inheritance from the founder obviously when the heir is a female, she must be deemed to have, what is known, as widows estate in the shebaiti interest.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Nature of shebaiti right settled; applies Hindu law of inheritance to females as limited estate despite alienation restrictions inherent to office.

holdings.text: The present suit is governed by Article 124 not Article 141 of the Limitation Act as shebaiti right is a hereditary office, not immovable property.

anchor.surface_text: But although we may not approve of this line of reasoning adopted by the High Court, we are in agreement with the learned Judges that the proper article to be applied in this case is article 124 and not article 141. There could be no doubt that there is an element in the shebaiti right which has the legal characteristics of property but shebaitship is property of a peculiar and anomalous character, and it is difficult to say that it comes under the category of immovable property as it is known in law.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Specific provision for hereditary office prevails over general immovable property; Art 141 expressly limited to immovable property; settled characterization of shebaiti right.

holdings.text: Article 124 requires adverse possession to the plaintiff or person from or through whom the plaintiff derives his right to sue (per s.2(8)); in case of reversioner succeeding Hindu widow, adverse possession commences only on her death.

anchor.surface_text: Reading article 124 of the Limitation Act along with section 2(8), the conclusion is irresistible that to defeat the title of the plaintiff under article 124 it is necessary to establish that the defendant had taken possession of the office adversely to the plaintiff or somebody from or through whom the plaintiff derives his title, more than 12 years prior to the institution of the suit. This is exactly what is laid down in Gnanasambanda v. Velu

holdings.reasoning_summary: Harmonious construction of Art 124 with definition of 'plaintiff' in s.2(8); reversioner does not derive through widow; applies Gnanasambanda precedent to hereditary office context.

holdings.text: The plaintiffs' suit is not barred by limitation.

anchor.surface_text: namely, whether or not the plaintiffs suit is barred by limitation. The trial court decided this point in favour of the plaintiffs, while the High Court has taken a contrary view in appeal.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Art 124 applies but possession adverse to reversioners only from Rajlakshmi's death on 22-12-1943; suit filed in 1944 within 12 years.

anchor.surface_text: We hold, therefore, that article 124 is the proper article to be applied, and the question now arises as to whether the plaintiffs suit is barred by limitation under this article, as has been held by the learned Judges of the High Court ?
